meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! I'm back with another groovy review for you, my fellow gamers!

I recently got my hands on the mystical puzzle adventure game, Chants of Sennaar, and let me tell you – it's a real linguistic treat! With its unique blend of translation puzzles, stealthy gameplay, and ancient mythology, this game had me chanting "More, please!" from start to finish.

Now, I know what you're thinking: "What about the critics?" Ah, those esteemed reviewers who get paid (in cookies?) to play games all day. Well, I've got a bone to pick with them – or rather, their scores. It seems like every single critic out there gave this game an 80 or 90! What's up with that? Are they trying to create some kind of linguistic consensus?

But enough about the critics. Let me tell you what I think: Chants of Sennaar is a real brain-twister, and I mean that in the best possible way. The puzzles are cleverly designed, requiring you to use your linguistic skills (or at least, pretend to be a genius like those reviewers) to unlock the secrets of ancient civilizations.

And then there's the stealth aspect – oh boy! Sneaking around, avoiding detection, and solving puzzles? It's like being a linguistic Lara Croft (minus the guns and tank tops). The checkpoint system is also super generous, so you don't have to worry about getting stuck in one spot for too long.

Now, I know some of you might be thinking, "But what about the presentation?" Well, let me tell you – it's alluring. Like a linguistic siren song, Chants of Sennaar will draw you in with its unique setting and captivating atmosphere.

In conclusion (drumroll please), if you're looking for a game that'll challenge your brain and make you feel like a genius, look no further than Chants of Sennaar! It's a linguistic masterpiece, if I do say so myself. And who knows? Maybe one day, I'll be the one reviewing games with scores... (Just kidding – I'll stick to being a humble reviewer.)

That's it for this review, folks! Stay groovy, and remember: always keep your wits about you – or at least, pretend to be a genius like those critics.
